node.title: July 2021 Fishing Report: Lower Sacramento   River
node.excerpt: The Lower Sacramento River out of Redding California has been fishing great. Water conditions are good and flows are topped off at 9,700 cubic feet per second. Starting next month, the upper section of the Lower Sac in Redding opens. On August 1st, the waters above HWY 44 open for Rainbow Trout Fishing. It’s an… Read More »
node.content:
The Lower Sacramento River out of Redding California has been fishing great. Water conditions are good and flows are topped off at 9,700 cubic feet per second.

Starting next month, the upper section of the Lower Sac in Redding opens. On August 1st, the waters above HWY 44 open for Rainbow Trout Fishing. It’s an exciting time harkening back to the old days when all of Californias trout streams opened on the last Saturday in April. It’s still a date to flag on the angling calendar, but as many rivers are now open year round, the celebratory atmosphere of that infamous Saturday has attenuated. But, show up at the Posse Grounds on August 1st in the morning and I promise you will see an angling spectacle.

What are the HOT flies on the Lower Sacramento River? The trout are almost always keying on Mayfly’s. Hatches of caddis have been noticeable this year. Summer time caddis can be fickle, but not this season.

  • PMD Mayfly Nymphs in #16 ~ #18
  • UV Jigged Birds Nest
  • Bubble Back Caddis
  • Peaches & Cream
  • Alt Rockers

My fly rod set up is pretty typical of the Lower Sacramento. 9’6″ leader length from indicator to split shot. I run a little more than one SSG. Some run two. Ya gotta get that leader straight in the turbulent water or due to the long leader length, the flies never make it down to the fish.

Sometimes, having a rod ready with a shorter, lighter drop for the riffles can be a help. I know some anglers who run dry/dropper set ups through the shallow riffles. But this switching of rods can be a major pain in the you know what. There’s a lot of river to fish. Pick a set up and drift the river. Equal opportunity all around.

With all the investment, flies, rod and boat, there’s one thing missing.

Experience.

I’m on the Lower Sacramento weekly. I know where to be and at what time. Some water fishes better in the afternoon. The Lower Sac doesn’t really start fishing until after 10:30 AM almost year round. In August, think 11:30AM on.

node.title: November 2021 Fishing Report: Lower Sacramento
node.excerpt: Heading into November and quieter times on the Lower Sacramento River out of Redding California. I missed a fishing report for October because it was busy and well, great fishing reports dominated the fly fishing web. November is quieter, but the fishing ensues as good as ever. It’s just that, by the end of October,… Read More »
node.content:
Heading into November and quieter times on the Lower Sacramento River out of Redding California. I missed a fishing report for October because it was busy and well, great fishing reports dominated the fly fishing web.

November is quieter, but the fishing ensues as good as ever. It’s just that, by the end of October, every angler who planned an Autumn trip to the Sac has been here.

November reports are always about the good fishing and solitude.

The spawning salmon are still here and the fish are eating eggs early morning in the shallow riffles. Peach pearl size 8mm and 10mm are hot.

I have been meeting groups/anglers at Bonnyview boat ramp and fishing to Anderson river park. With recent heavy rains boats have been stacking up fishing from the Posse Grounds (highest access allowing navigation of the river in Redding) in the morning and pulling out at Bonny View.

The river below Bonny View is effected easily by swelling creeks which turn the river brown with churning mud making for poor fishing conditions.

In the better water above Bonnie View, I usually will add a brown rubber legs to the mix after late morning and heavy boat traffic can move the rainbows off the spawning beds “reds” they will seem to key on rubber legs and keep biting into the afternoon.

There’s always something interesting going on.

Water conditions will improve over the next few days and I expect great fishing down to Anderson River Park and beyond. That clearing, green water always puts fish on the bite.

My November and December are flexible, but dates book up fast as good reports ensue and they will.

node.title: Lake Shasta Fishing Report: June 2021
node.excerpt: Lake Shasta is fishing great! My fishing reports for Lake Shasta are short. I provide a very brief fishing report including poor or good fishing, a hot lure, the fish we are finding, weather, and a forecast of what to expect on Lake Shasta over the next 4 to 6 weeks. Fishing has been good!… Read More »
node.content:
Lake Shasta is fishing great!

My fishing reports for Lake Shasta are short. I provide a very brief fishing report including poor or good fishing, a hot lure, the fish we are finding, weather, and a forecast of what to expect on Lake Shasta over the next 4 to 6 weeks.

Fishing has been good!

Shad are just starting to show up in the main body of Shasta Lake. What does that mean? Well, where there’s shad we find concentrations of feeding fish like kokanees, rainbow trout, and brown trout. The idea is to fill the cooler with a limit of these tasty fish. Not Shad though.

For now, I’m finding fish, but they are scattered around the vastness of Lake Shasta. So we are on the move a lot, fishing, searching, catching, repeat. Which is kinda a plus for sight seeing.

I might find 5 fish, or 20.

Currently, I’m fishing at a depth of 15-70 feet.

Lures include small spoons. To get them down it’s downriggers, planner boards. Trolling speed is about 2.5 mph.

I expect good fishing through out the next few weeks. Typically, we experience great fishing throughout the summer on Lake Shasta.

Bring your sunscreen, a hat, sunglasses and lets fish!

node.title: Nov. 2020 Lower Sacramento River Fishing Report
node.excerpt: The egg bite is strong on the lower Sacramento River! Well it’s that time of year and the lower Sacramento River rainbow trout are feeding on eggs. King salmon are everywhere and spawning is in full swing, theses hungry bows are scattered all over the spawning beds (known as a “redd”) making for great fishing.… Read More »
node.content:
The egg bite is strong on the lower Sacramento River!

Well it’s that time of year and the lower Sacramento River rainbow trout are feeding on eggs.

King salmon are everywhere and spawning is in full swing, theses hungry bows are scattered all over the spawning beds (known as a “redd”) making for great fishing.

It’s no secret among eager trout fishermen that this is the time to hit the river, so be prepared for busy launch ramps and lots of activity on your favorite stretch of river.

Getting up early is key right now beating the traffic is paying off big time.

With steady traffic, the salmon and the trout are being pushed off their redds due to so many boats which scatter the fish. The fishing can be less than productive at times. The hot fly is a pegged 8 or 10mm bead. The color and size will change daily so make sure to have plenty of options.

The bite is best early and don’t be afraid to fish shallow water! Trout are not very tall so sometimes only a few inches of water are all need as they are positioned just downstream of spawning salmon.

Good luck out there and be safe!

node.title: Lower Sacramento River Fishing Report – September 2020
node.excerpt: Lower Sacramento River is hot! The big fish are here, on this upper section of the Lower Sacramento, located in Redding California. What’s in the future for the Lower Sacramento River and it’s wild Rainbow Trout? Once October arrives, the great fishing will continue to prevail as spawning King Salmon and lower river flows change… Read More »
node.content:
Lower Sacramento River is hot!

The big fish are here, on this upper section of the Lower Sacramento, located in Redding California.

What’s in the future for the Lower Sacramento River and it’s wild Rainbow Trout? Once October arrives, the great fishing will continue to prevail as spawning King Salmon and lower river flows change the fishng experence from drifting deep water to opportunity along the shallow gravel bars where Rainbow Trout over 20″ are commonly found eating the stray eggs laid by spawning King Salmon.

For now, with changes on the horizon what’s working now may change but the hot bugs/flies have been:

  • S & M Hogan’s size #18
  • Poxyback PMD’s #18 ~16
  • Birds Nest #14 ~12

Long leaders, over 9′ to the split shot are getting the flies to the fish (I’m fishing under indicators.

By this time next month, the hot set up will be pegged orange beads as the Rainbows definitely key on King Salmon Eggs.

Best fly is called a “keep your eye on the indicator”. My personal secret. Works 100% of the time.

See you out on the river!

node.title: Lake Shasta Fishing Report | September 2020
node.excerpt: The fishing on Lake Shasta has been a battle this summer. Still worth fishing! With low water this year the lake has suffered an almost nonexistent shad spawn and has caused really hard fishing. It seems the Rainbow Trout have been feeding on bluegill, but as a food source that it is, bluegill simply do… Read More »
node.content:
The fishing on Lake Shasta has been a battle this summer. Still worth fishing!

With low water this year the lake has suffered an almost nonexistent shad spawn and has caused really hard fishing. It seems the Rainbow Trout have been feeding on bluegill, but as a food source that it is, bluegill simply do not supply the opportunity to feed in volume like shad provide. So, maybe that’s why we are not finding quite as many of the large late summer Rainbow Trout we have come to expect. We are finding some, but we are just not meeting the standards set by previous seasons.

Some days are great! Smiles and limits are happening, it’s just that I have “my” standards and how I feel about the fishing. I think it could be a lot better. The quality of the fishing on Lake Shasta will vary year to year.

My year on Lake Shasta is coming to an end as I get ready for fall and winter steelhead fishing on the rivers like the Trinity River. I am still fishing Lake Shasta for the remainder of September and do have some open dates.

Overall it’s still worth fishing and there are chances of a banner day but it can be very tuff at worst, a banner day at best.

Remember, no matter what, it’s still fishing and luck plays a part in our time on the water.

node.title: Lower Sacramento River Redding | Fishing Report August 2020
node.excerpt: It’s time! August on the Lower Sacramento River out of Redding CA. is arguably the best time to fish this river for it’s extra-large wild Rainbow Trout. Not sure what it is, but by mid August through mid September, the bite always seems to be dominated by fish averaging 18″. 20+” fish are expected. So… Read More »
node.content:
It’s time! August on the Lower Sacramento River out of Redding CA. is arguably the best time to fish this river for it’s extra-large wild Rainbow Trout.

Not sure what it is, but by mid August through mid September, the bite always seems to be dominated by fish averaging 18″. 20+” fish are expected.

So bring the camera!!! These are wild fish. We can’t take any. All catch and release.

A special section of river, normally closed from the last Saturday in April through July 31st is now open. From the Posse Ground, downstream under the famous Sun Dial Bridge, the very upper reaches of the Lower Sac through Redding, CA produce what in my opinion and based on my experience, the best Wild Rainbow Trout fishing in the west. I’m talking solid, big, powerful rainbow trout.

As sun gets high in the sky, insect activity drives the fishing and there’s lots of opportunity along the edges of the river, in shallower water where we can find Rainbow Trout gulping caddis and mayflies.

Anglers who have that right bug ? under there indicator are hooking 5 to 25 fish a day and the fish hogs, they pull hard. Bring an arm sling for the drive home.

My hot fly has been a jig head birds nest with 4x on a long leader.

If you hesitate to book your trip, you will miss the strike! The bite will slow in the weeks to come as the salmon move in to spawn. Then it’s another pond all together, different tactics and a rainbow that’s a little tougher to get.

Still, no matter what time of year, the Lower Sacramento always kicks out productive fishing (except when flows rise and that’s not for a while.. next spring).

October, November, December, January all produce good fishing, but right now is one for the books. Do it.

See you on the river!

node.title: Whiskeytown Lake | Fishing Report | August 2020
node.excerpt: The news of Whiskeytown Lake is spreading fast. A copepod infestation is in full swing! The Kokanee are covered in them. A copepod is basically a tick for a fish. It sticks to the skin and sucks nutrients from the fish. This causes stunted growth, lethargic behavior as well as major skin irritation and excess… Read More »
node.content:
The news of Whiskeytown Lake is spreading fast.

A copepod infestation is in full swing! The Kokanee are covered in them. A copepod is basically a tick for a fish. It sticks to the skin and sucks nutrients from the fish. This causes stunted growth, lethargic behavior as well as major skin irritation and excess slime.

Although the Kokanee are not harmful to eat, the Kokanee are unsightly and off the bite.

I still have been running trips with full disclosure to my clients and for the most part, been catching plenty of fish. They have been deep and holding close to the bottom with early morning being the best time to hook up.

Expect to get a good number of fish. Check-in with me, but I see no reason why we won’t limit out with you going home with some really nice filets for the grill!

node.title: Whiskey Town Lake Fishing Report: Late March 2020
node.excerpt: Whiskey Town Lake is pumping out limits of chrome Kokanee!! It’s early and we are bagging daily limits of big early season fish up to 17.5 inches! The water is cold and fish are coming from the surface in the morning down to 50 feet in later morning and afternoon. Remember to fish long set… Read More »
node.content:
Whiskey Town Lake is pumping out limits of chrome Kokanee!!

It’s early and we are bagging daily limits of big early season fish up to 17.5 inches!

The water is cold and fish are coming from the surface in the morning down to 50 feet in later morning and afternoon.

Remember to fish long set backs when fishing the surface down to 20 feet.

Later in the day, as the sun warms the surface, 30 and 50 foot depths have been very consistent.

I fish exclusively Paulina Peak Tackle. Their Orange Micro Shrimp as well as their Chartreuse Micro Shrimp have been solid producers. As always their Pink Micro Hoochies and Cotton Candy Big Eye Doger are a go-to fish killers. Its looking like a great summer ahead with really good Kokanee fishing to look forward to.

Take a break and get out on the water with me for some real social distancing!

node.title: Shasta Lake Fishing Report | August 2020
node.excerpt: Lake Shasta has been tuff with a slow transition this year to turn over the shad in the lake (bait fish) are slow to mature. This is making locating schools of feeding fish difficult. A variety of different tactics must be employed to catch fish. I’m using downriggers, dypsy divers, and planer boards all in… Read More »
node.content:
Lake Shasta has been tuff with a slow transition this year to turn over the shad in the lake (bait fish) are slow to mature. This is making locating schools of feeding fish difficult. A variety of different tactics must be employed to catch fish.

I’m using downriggers, dypsy divers, and planer boards all in the same day. Some times with great success others with mild results, better days are ahead I believe the fishing will get better in the lake and the shad will eventually fill out to normal size. Fish are being caught on the surface to 100 feet. For me, slow trolling spoons on my downriggers have been my go too but it often changes.

Reach out to me (Alex) below or leave a comment and I’ll get right back to you, typically within 24 hours!
